author: {'steamid': '76561198041856540', 'num_games_owned': 919, 'num_reviews': 275, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1679800378}
review:
A fairly polished minesweeper game, it gives what it says on the tin, a seemingly endless queue of minesweeper boards.

Overall it feels like this game was made for the pro / competitive scene - as a casual player I found its UI, scoring and item systems overly strict to the degree that borders on player-hostile. Eg. you have a few seconds to grab items, and the game happily lets you waste items without explaining what they do.

I think the experience's most significant downside comes from the weakness of the minesweeper genre itself - namely that at a large proportion of games you are reduced to guessing, as there is no logical step forward. I think it's part of the reason why I prefer picross to minesweeper.

Still leaning towards a recommended rating, as Fine Sweeper does what it sets out to do, and at a competent quality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048092359', 'num_games_owned': 1702, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1672667423}
review:
It is minesweeper, the client is decent there is some general progression but the new mechanics this game adds aren't all that impactful or fun. Some of the achievements are good while others are pointless grindy achievements (takes about 2-3 hours to step on mines and farm flagged bombs)

I'm not exactly sure who is the target audience for this game. Competitive players play on minesweeper.online, if you want a total conversion game you should check out demoncrawl instead. The only reason for this game to exist is so your boomer dad doesn't have to play the terrible freemium minesweeper game that windows tries to push nowadays.

author: {'steamid': '76561198234584076', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 5441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5441, 'last_played': 1636998759}
review:
That was a great, addictive game. A bunch of challenging achs, luckily there're helpful guides and discussions, including dev's help. Gosh, I'm glad I finally beat it completely \o/ I really need to play similar games as rarely as possible, practically impossible to stop xD Anyway, thanks for it. 

There's that state of being tired when I can't focus on reading my fav visual novels but not too exhausted to actually go to bed, that's where I could indulge myself in playing this. Plus, I could combine playing it and listening to different educational youtube viseos. So, it wasn't a complete waste of time. It always feels good for me when I can do effectively different activities.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965215862', 'num_games_owned': 4216, 'num_reviews': 525, 'playtime_forever': 1022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1022, 'last_played': 1615588778}
review:
[h1]ğŸ® [u]Fine Sweeper[/u] ğŸ® [/h1] 

Die bisher einzige VerÃ¶ffentlichung von [url=https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Pixel%20Prophecy]Pixel Prophecy[/url] auf Steam, hÃ¼llt den Klassiker Mine Sweeper in ein neues Gewandt und bietet uns Dank ein paar Herausforderungen, die es zu erfÃ¼llen gilt um alle Errungenschaften zu erhalten, auch einen gewissen wettkampforientierten Modus. Das Spielprinzip selbst blieb gleich: HeiÃŸt man klickt auf einem Feld mit lauter versteckten Bomben herum und markiert diese anhand dessen was die freigeschalteten Zahlen einem sagen. Je weiter man kommt, desto komplizierter die Level - 50 an der Zahl. Doch in dieser Version hat man mit Herzen (=Leben) und anderen Gimmicks die MÃ¶glichkeit nicht beim ersten Fehltritt Game Over zu sein. Es ist diesbezÃ¼glich Benutzer freundlicher. Grafisch ist das Ganze eine 2D-OberflÃ¤che und akustisch nichts Weltbewegendes.
 
[b]Fazit[/b] 

Wer den Klassiker mochte, findet hier eine neue Herausforderung die optisch verbessert wurde. Der Schwierigkeitsgrad steigt kontinuierlich und durch die Herausforderungen gibt es auch eine Art Wettbewerb. Insofern sind die 2,99 Euro ganz gut investiert, auch wenn man das Rad nicht neu erfindet. Circa 17 Stunden Spielzeit sprechen denke ich fÃ¼r sich!

[i]Wenn ihr an weiteren Rezensionen von mir interessiert seid oder meine Arbeit unterstÃ¼tzen wollt, dann folgt meiner [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/GermanReviewGroup]Gruppe[/url] und/oder der [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/32139821/]Kuration[/url][/i].

author: {'steamid': '76561198075324976', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 689, 'playtime_forever': 11808, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 319, 'last_played': 1700028768}
review:
Minesweeper + Quality of Life Improvements = Fine Sweeper
---

If it wasn't obvious enough from the store page, Fine Sweeper could easily be called a clone of Minesweeper. But it's not quite a clone, it's a much improved variant that offers a greater sense of progression, less random failures (that aren't your fault) and numerous other (minor) improvements that total up to a much better game than the one it's cloned from.

If you already know what Minesweeper is and want a better version of it, this is a no brainer. It's a cheap and pleasant way to kill some time and play with brain teasing puzzles.

If you aren't familiar with Minesweeper, it's a classic game that used to be included with early versions of Windows operating systems to give people a fun way to practice their mouse clicking skills (yes, prior to a mouse being a ubiquitous and common tool, people honestly didn't know how to use the thing well). These days (for whatever reason) it's no longer included by default with Windows 10, but can be found for free through various sources.

Sometimes you just want a simple relaxing series of puzzles to chip away the hours.
---

EDIT: I've been playing this game a lot more lately. I guess I just have a thing for simple puzzles and minesweeper was something of an addiction 30 years ago, so here we are all over again. If I have one issue with this game it's the repetitive music. Of course, most of you already know how easy it is to solve that: Just turn down the music (not the sound effects) and listen to your own music.

Well, just for the heck of it, here's what I've been listening to while playing:
[url=https://www.pandora.com/station/play/3177130842444665891]Tech N9ne Radio (Channel) on Pandora (music streaming service)[/url]

If you are outside of their service area, might I suggest looking for something like Great Dane - Alpha Dog or Tech N9ne all 6's and 7's.
https://youtu.be/VQMjdpQ6tZU
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K-VY3-maw34&list=PLSzyhyWhtDtIYcUdRuCWi_qeNWpsEsLmw Anyway, find your jam and just chill.

review:
For $3, its a pretty nice minesweeper game. Well, its minesweeper, that's what you can expect with that. Better than Microsoft's Minesweeper you can get from the Window's Store that'll blast your eardrums out with ads every few games. 10/10. Better than Microsoft.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965441477', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 909, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 903, 'last_played': 1595772907}
review: If you know how to play the game, then you probably already know you like it. This game's levels of increasing difficulty challenge your math skills and thinking. author: {'steamid': '76561198032457930', 'num_games_owned': 1841, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1605833848}
review:
General: 



Rating: None (Probably E though)
Price: $2.99
Genre: Puzzle
Time played: 2.5 hours 

Did you enjoy minesweeper?  This game is a minesweeper variant with extra features. You get lives, thereâ€™s score keeping and of course Achievements. As a fan of minesweeper I really enjoyed the game. 

Gameplay -  9

This is a pretty niche type of game. If you donâ€™t like minesweeper you probably wonâ€™t care for this game. If you have never played the game the basic idea is that you are sweeping for mines.  You pick a square and if itâ€™s not a mine. Good job. If it is you blow up. Now if itâ€™s not a bomb it will either be a blank space or a space with a number in it.  If itâ€™s blank. Move on to another space. The number tells you how many mines are in the 8 squares around that 1 square.  From there itâ€™s just using logic to figure out where the mines are located. 

Story -  N/A



Graphics -  8

Pretty decent, easy to read and there is no confusion.  Not much else to say. 


Controls - MouseKeyboard -10

You left click to uncover a single square, right click to mark mines. Left and right click on a number, that already has associated mines marked,  and itâ€™ll clear out all the area it can around. 
Thatâ€™s pretty much it, you can also mark ?â€™s but I take off that feature in options. 

Repeatability - 8

Itâ€™s mine sweeper, youâ€™re going to be playing the levels over and over.  Thereâ€™s an achievement to get to level 7 in less than 1 minute. Not impossible, but difficult enough that youâ€™ll be playing the first 6 levels over and over a few times. 



Music - ???

Itâ€™s there? Usually while gaming I listen to my own music, unless itâ€™s a sound based game. 

Multiplayer - N/A 

Pretty sure there is not multiplayer, but there are online leaderboards.


Initial Thoughts: 

Oh a minesweeper type game. I havenâ€™t played that game since I was a kid. Interesting you can earn extra lives and such.   


Soma Says: 

Normally I like to put in a good 10 or so hours into a game before reviewing it.  However, this game is an easy exception. Iâ€™ve put 100â€™s if not 1000â€™s into the original minesweeper.  I live an exciting life as you can tell. 

The addition of extra lives is a good one, itâ€™s frustrating to hit a mine because you made a stupid mistake and have to start all over. This is just a more forgiving version of minesweeper. 

If you enjoyed minesweeper you might want to pick this up.  If you like sudoku puzzles or any type of logic puzzles this is a game you will most likely enjoy.  Also itâ€™s 3 bucks.  Not exactly breaking the bank here. 


If you enjoyed the review check out my curator page : https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28849369/

author: {'steamid': '76561198129680513', 'num_games_owned': 802, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 3460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1709301925}
review:
Best minesweeper game.

Totally love the BGM.

Right clicking the opened number can also automatically opens the remaining boxes, very helpful.

I love the idea of having lives, so that you get chance to click mines and not starting over, because it is very common to end up in an unsolvable situation that you have to depend on possibilities.

Also this game made it so that first click is guaranteed to be safe. Getting mine on first click is not very nice.

The thing I hate in this game is that there are 2 achievements that are very grindy.

I give this 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198099019213', 'num_games_owned': 2407, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3035, 'last_played': 1585415188}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Fine Sweeper is based on minesweeper game with a few features.

[h1]Features[/h1]
Heart for extra lives
abilities :  [spoiler] you can unlock one ability by eating heart at full life, this ability change with how many heart . Once the ability is used, you need to eat heart again. [/spoiler]

[b]how to play[/b]: let you learn the basics and tips of minesweeper game in general.
[b]custom mode[/b]: you set the board with how many mine you want.
[b]campaign mode[/b]: The board gets bigger and mines are more numerous each level. You can add [b]classic mode[/b] (one heart) for extra challenge.
[b]leaderboard[/b] high score from campaign mode and classic mode.

[h1]100% achievement[/h1]
[spoiler] nothing difficult, a few are [b]very[/b] grindy [/spoiler]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Heart is a good "counter measure" against [i] no guessing-free boad[/i].
Very good minesweeper game for beginner and fan of minesweeper alike.
You can check your place on the leaderboad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079300966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1508, 'last_played': 1632342855}
review:
[h1][b]Fine Sweeper - Better Than The Original[/b][/h1]

I have to be honest, I hated the original game since it wasn't a puzzle game, it was a guessing game disguised as a puzzle game. You would get to points in the original where you just can't know what the right answer is and had to guess which more often than not would result in you blowing yourself up and starting over. Happily I can say that this version of Minesweeper is improved a lot from it's original 1989 counter-part. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
Pffffahaha, yeah right...

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay of Minesweeper is where it really shines. As much as you can play many other copies of Minesweeper for free on the internet, this paid for version on steam introduces a few new features that really help the game elevate itself from it's thousands of copycats.

The way to win at this game is to empty out a grid where mines have been placed randomly around that grid. You click on one of these squares and it reveals an area with a number. These number indicate how many mines are in the surrounding area around that number. If a number is surrounded by 8 other squares and the number is 3 that means that 3 out of those 8 squares have bombs in them. By revealing more areas you gain more information that you can use to dig out the mines safely.

[b]*Useful Features*[/b]
I like to put special emphasis on these new features since they are the only reason why I am not telling you to just play Minesweeper for free on the internet instead of paying 3â‚¬ for this steam version.

[b]Multiple lives[/b]
The inclusion of multiple lives makes it so that even if you do get to a point where you just have to guess it's not as devastating to get it wrong since you just lose one of multiple lives and can carry on instantly afterwards compared to the older ones that didn't allow you to make a single mistake. This feature fixed the biggest standing issue I had with the game.

[b]Collateral Damage[/b]
Something I really enjoy is that if you do get so unfortunate to click on a mine and it blows up, when it explodes it also destroys the surrounding squares except for other mines meaning it can reveal other mines for you if you mess up. I enjoy this but also am a bit conflicted since it kind of feels like you are being rewarded for being wrong by being shown where other mines are. I do think however that this is something that can be disabled/enable in the options menu so it's not a problem, but I still think this feature is nice for someone that might be struggling with a certain level, and speaking of levels.

[b]Levels[/b]
The first Minesweeper game I have played that actually have levels and a rise in difficulty. It works really great because it keeps the player engaged and is a great way to have levels that are better tailored towards a particular players skill level. This is a huge improvement from the other games that only have "Beginner, Intermediate and Expert". This allows for a much bigger ranger of maps and difficulties to suit other players.

[b]Powers[/b]
While clearing out a grid you can stumble upon hearts on the field, if you have made a mistake earlier in the game you can left click on the heart and it fills out one of your heart containers, alternatively if you right click on it it gets added to a meter at the bottom left corner that after you have gathered enough hearts can be used for powers that help clear the grid a bit easier. The more hearts you invest in the meter the better the power will be when you use it which I found myself ignoring since I would rather just get the health but if your health is full it might be a good investment in the long run!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is great! I finally enjoy Minesweeper as a puzzle game and it feels really rewarding when you complete a level! This version has fixed long standing issues with the games and for that alone I think it is finally worth playing and even paying the little amount it asks for! I recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004190775', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2021, 'last_played': 1604263498}
review:
Click click BOOM !

Nice simple game to understand, hours of relaxed fun. The type of game you play if you are on the phone to someone or watching TV, as doesn't take up too much concentration. It's a multitask or contemplation time, type of game.

Only slight downside is the hidden achievement ' flag 50000 bombs'. this is going to take you a while, so if you are the type of person who doesn't normally bother to flag the bombs, i would get in the habit from the start  - as will save you some time. But as this is the type of game you pick up every so often, it's not a big deal about the length of time as it always has continued playability to it, so will get them all in the end - just keep playing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198262864341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1518917783}
review: A fine version of Minesweeper, better than the windows version for sure unless you are a die hard fan of the traditional no options approach.  I liked what this version could offer.  But in the end, it couldn't hold my attention much more than original minesweeper did.  Fun enough to try one day, but there are a lot more interesting games for me to play than this one, so I'm moving on. [3 / 5 stars].

author: {'steamid': '76561198001572563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 3461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1669, 'last_played': 1561467343}
review:
Wirklich gutes Minesweeper Spiel! FÃ¼r Leute die das Spiel gern spielen kÃ¶nnen bei 3â‚¬ nichts falsch machen. Es gibt ein globales Leaderboard das sehr motiviert und 3 Modi. Einmal der klassische mit einem Leben und einmal mit mehreren Leben. Das ist super fÃ¼r die nervigen 50/50 Chancen! Bei beiden spielt man von einem Level in den nÃ¤chsten. Die werden stehts schwieriger. Der 3. Modus ist der Custom mode.

Fine Sweeper bietet auch alle Funktionen die man so kennt wie zB das Audecken aller umliegenden Felder wenn man alle Minen eines Zahlenfelds markiert hat. Desweiteren kann man das Aussehen etwas anpassen.

Das einzige, dass etwas stÃ¶rt sind die 2 Grind-Achievements die am Schluss Ã¼brig bleiben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198085522430', 'num_games_owned': 625, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1663449007}
review: This is the best way to play Minesweeper. An amazing version of it with a nice clean and creative look. If you like Minesweeper and want to improve, play this bad boy. It has some fun varied game modes and settings which can help you really get a hang of things. It also has some nice quick clearing functions that I will beg for in any Minesweeper I play from now on. A fantastic and my go-to way to play this classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 230, 'last_played': 1643039338}
review:
Tags: Clicker - Slow
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from LIbrary

TLDR: Minesweeper was free on windows and we all felt the need to get real games rather than the windows supplied ones due to their low fun factor.

The game can easily be resized with the HUD buttons and while it remains simple, there are small animations, FX for bombs going off and the health system was a really neat little touch as well as a smal campaign mode to supplement the custom board option.

Conclusion: If you are okay to go grid based, Hexcells remains servicable. However for the purists who want that classic minesweeper feel, this is an excellent direct step up which sticks to the core presentation and formula that made the original great. I suspect there are actually few people who would play this on a regular enough basis or have enough of an interest to obtain it outside of bundle purchases and in my case I see it best to archive it in hidden library.

Fine Sweeper Ã¨ un gioco gustoso che regala molte emozioni ed Ã¨ utile a chi deve affrontare l'esame di Analisi 2 in Ingegneria. Per pochi euro potrete raggiungere, con solo due ore giornaliere di allenamento su questo gioco, lo stesso QI di Stiven Okking che dall'alto del cielo vi proteggerÃ  e vi regalerÃ  sane emozioni al gusto di fragola.

Il gioco fila liscio il frame rate stabile sui 60 fps (ricordiamo che l'occhio umano non vede oltre) ci regala la fluiditÃ  nelle animazioni fatte da 2 frame che andranno smooth anche sui calcolatori piÃ¹ deboli grazie al grande lavoro di ottimizzazione fatto dagli sviluppatori.

Questo T I T O L O Ã¨ di una vastitÃ  e profonditÃ  di gameplay talmente alta e deep che le menti piÃ¹ geniali troveranno comunque divertimento nell'affrontare la sfida principale del gioco. Peccato l'assenza di modalitÃ  aggiuntive e di una modalitÃ  multi player.

In sintesi, tornando a noi, vi sconsiglio di comprarlo perchÃ© si potrebbe rivelare piÃ¹ pericoloso del crocodile.

author: {'steamid': '76561198152087110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1529863582}
review:
Game is fun for a while, but on reflection it's not that much different from playing Windows Minesweeper. Has cards and achievements, and is a little more lenient because you have lives, I suppose.

Personally I found the soundtrack really annoying, so I turned it off. Dev was kind enough to show me how to hide/turn off the timer, which was nice.

My reccomendation is still a no though. What I disliked about the game most was still the feeling of time pressure. As someone with anxiety, it's just not for me. If you like that kind of thing in your games though, then by all means go for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065042197', 'num_games_owned': 804, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 8084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6342, 'last_played': 1697330704}
review: It's minesweeper but with the ability to make mistakes and keep going thanks to its life system. This addition has two benefits: first, it helps you overcome the frustration the classic windows time waster could  bring when you had a promising run stopped abrubtly by an impossible-to-guess mine. Second, it adds a new level of strategy missing from the original game since you can use your lives as a resource to maximize the information you get from an explosion. Overall, this version keeps the core addictive gameplay of the original while adding much needed improvements.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039353230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4517, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4409, 'last_played': 1516936514}
review:
[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Hearts: Accumulate hearts as "extra lives" when you may need to guess
[*]Background: Very attractive themes (e.g., Doctor Who)
[*]Colors: The board's color changes as well as text in the squares
[*]Right Click: Using a right-click on a square allows you to uncover adjacent squares when you've isloated a solution.  This aids in removing some "human error" scenarios once the player has fixed a solution for a square. 
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Achievements: Some of the achievements are luck based, but you can still get them by grinding away enough.
[*]Colors: At times, the game picks some colors that don't contrast well.  However, you can resolve this by completing the board, or just restarting your progress.
[/list]

Overall, I high recommend this game if you liked the original.  It is so much improved over the original version that came bundled with Windows.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992949422', 'num_games_owned': 2059, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1508275001}
review:
It is minesweeper. But a very nice version.  In Kampain Mode you try to solve increasingly harder levels until you loose all your hearts. That is fun.  
The music reminds me of bomb defusal scenes in mission impossible. NIce. 
Just noticed there was an update that makes the game even better. 
Not much else to say.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121161049', 'num_games_owned': 313, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 684, 'last_played': 1481368743}
review:
Minesweeper with a few new introduced modes.

Not much more to say, except that the game still is fun as heck, even though you can still eventually run into situations where you have to guess which tile is a mine and which not. But that ever existing problem of the game mechanics aside it can fill your nostalgia and retro puzzle hunger every now and then.

Plus point: Seemingly I had an issue and the developer contacted me and we worked it out (was just a wrong understanding from my side, but great to see the support!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198054982103', 'num_games_owned': 1994, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 4780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4749, 'last_played': 1496879463}
review: Well... Honestly, this game took me back a fair few years, exploring windows and finding the games tab, where i discovered Mine Sweeper, but could never understand the game and gave up trying to learn how the game worked. Fast forward 12 years, i discovered Fine Sweeper, the cheesey named modern version of the classic game itself. Nostagia at its finest, and with an understanding of the game like never before, the first 40 levels were smooth, and enjoyable. Then the challenges set in... 60 hours in, and 60 levels down the line, I found myself needing 1 more achievement for thorough success, so, me being me, i looked into it... "Flag 50,000 bombs"... FIFTY THOUSAND!! BOMBS!! This game took its toll on me... Now i'm sat here, slowly rocking, talking to an empty Lucozade bottle filled with urine! <3 I LOVE IT! 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198204159008', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 374, 'last_played': 1484918311}
review:
This is Minesweeper with more than one life (the player can be granted up to seven lives at a time). As Minesweeper is half-deterministic and can be played as "classic mode" in Fine Sweeper as well, Fine Sweeper can be seen as an extended version of Minesweeper including an editor for random maps created from the following data: 
- Height (of the rectangle)
- Width  (of the rectangle)
- Number of bombs to encounter
The standard campaign, where the size of the randomized rectangles rises continuously with the number of bombs, is supposed to be played till level 51 and beyond, which, for friends of Minesweeper, signifies a clear recommendation.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063144502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 29866, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11417, 'last_played': 1701553427}
review:
I'll admit that the original minesweeper from the 90's was my favorite way to procrastinate and waste time whenever I had important assignments due or serious finals to study for.  I've spent hours playing it straight into the wee hours of the morning only to realize at 6am that I was completely screwed because I hadn't yet started writing that essay or even cracked open a text book.  Nothing like turning on the computer with the very best of intentions and thinking "hey I'll just play one game to get my brain going before I get started" only to fail miserably every time.  Ah, the nostalgia...

If you were a fan of the original minesweeper, this game is a must have for your steam library.  It plays much like the original and has some added improvements which makes it even more addicting if you can believe it.  Multiple modes are included in the game, my favorite one being the campaign mode which progressively gets harder the more you advance.  I've long since collected every achievement in the game but I keep playing it because the challenge is so enjoyable .  

I find this game to be very satisfying and relaxing but I don't think everyone will feel the same way.  If you are on the fence about it, I would suggest playing the free 90's version first to see if you enjoy it at all.  If you don't, you likely won't like this one either.

UPDATE 11/26/17:  I am nominating this game for the "No Apologies" award category in the 2017 Autumn Awards.  As of today I am STILL playing this game, and no one I know in real life can understand why I'm so into it.  I don't really understand it either but the important thing is I'm still having fun and don't care what anyone thinks.  =)

author: {'steamid': '76561198110366993', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 9440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4637, 'last_played': 1698204237}
review: This is a hell of a dangerous way to become obsessed with minesweeper, a game I would never expect myself to love. After 80 some odd hours (90% of which are on lvl's 60+ :) ) I have developed more of a mind for puzzle games, getting multiple variations on my phone etc. which has, in turn, made me feel sharper and has developed my deduction skills and probably numerous other brain areas. I absolutely love the communal vibe to this game because I feel like I'm a part of a slightly more niche group of people who are genuinely interested and invested in this game. I'll have to take notes from now on, marking things I like and maybe some points of interest because I can't help but want to give input to the awesome dev(s).

author: {'steamid': '76561197971341065', 'num_games_owned': 3377, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 4522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4501, 'last_played': 1454176064}
review:
A decent expansion of the gameplay of windows minesweeper with a smoother difficulty curve, a scoring system to reward being able to play quickly while still being accurate/correct, and a campaign mode where you can accumulate lives and try to progress as many levels as you can without making too many mistakes or losing out when forced to guess from multiple possible solutions, while the purist can play in classic mode for the same game play as the original if desired.

Overall it plays very smoothly, has a good range of options over the original concept it expands on, and could keep you occupied for many hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028673669', 'num_games_owned': 7010, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1455566767}
review:
The trailer says - Waste time like it's 92 - and you know what? This game as great as it was when you were playing Minesweeper 20 years go. Srsly, personally I always liked minesweeper more than solitary, and I was pretty skeptical about this game but:

+Visuals: Very nice design of the levels, colorful, every some levels it changes the color palette so you won't get bored, various settings, mmmm :3
+Gameplay: 1st of all the gameplay is a bit improved all around but not as much so you won't say it that this game is too casual or different from the original. You have the campaign to advance through multiple levels with increasing difficulties, you have a lot of achievements to beat, you can play with or without lives so if you fĞ¸ck up on the last cornered mines you can continue playing. I like everything about this game seriously. All the old features like flags and left+right click detections are still here :)
+Sound work is okay
+Steam cards
+Steam achievements

So overall I enjoyed everything in this game and its also cheap AF AND it goes on sale sometimes so with the cards price you can obtain this gem nearly free.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017089678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1688587461}
review:
pros:
- it's just the minesweeper we know!

cons:
- it's just the minesweeper we know..

No but seriously, I got it with a coupon for cheaper, I wouldn't have bought it for full price. I just like minesweeper and my OS doesn't have it. I could perhaps play it online free somewhere, but now I have it in my steam library and it looks somewhat decent.

One thing that I find annoying is, you can't restart a new game. You HAVE to purposely die so you can select a new game. Otherwhise your only option is to 'resume' the old game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093220384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 1510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1569222067}
review:
For those who've never run a Windows device, or are just too young to have really caught the original game in its prime, back in the day when you had to open a hatch and shovel coal in to power your PC, or sacrifice some of your blood into the little funnel on the top and get it to run for an extra 66.06 minute's worth of use, there were two games that were all the rage for everyone from the lowliest peasant to the wealthiest king, many of which would spend [i]literally[/i] millions on a new machine just to play them and nothing else. I am of course talking about Solitaire and Minesweeper. Solitaire has already seen several enjoyable re-workings, but now it's Minesweeper's time to shine with a modern update in the form of Fine Sweeper. And you know what?... It ain't half bad.

Presented with a grid full of square panels that are hiding several mines underneath, you click on a panel and reveal some blank spaces and some numbers. Each number represents how many mines surround that tile, and based on that information, you must deduce the locations of every mine and avoid them as you click and remove all the unoccupied panels on the board. With each cleared grid, you move on to another that's either bigger and/or has more mines hiding from you. Make a mistake and you'll have a fully primed ball explode in your face. Do that several times, and it's game over.

The difference with this update is it's far more lenient than its original granddaddy. You now have hearts that allow you some breathing room where each heart will give you a free pass should you click on a mine, more of which can be found hiding under some random squares that can be used to replenish your stock and give you more room for mistakes. Or, alternatively, instead of using them you can save them in a bank and eventually cash them in for special, one-time use abilities to help you clear the board. And for hardcore score enthusiasts, this version has scoreboards for you, too, along with additional methods of play available to maximise that goal.

A little extra flair is added with some clean, appealing visuals (the grid and its surrounding boarder resembling the top-down dungeons from the original NES Zelda) and some funky bass licks to keep the mood up from stage to stage. It's all perfectly pleasant and functional and serves as a nice, relaxed, modern take on a fun but dated classic. I'm not sure how many stages there are, as I stopped at the 50 required for the achievements, but with multiple stages of increasing difficulty, a custom mode with sliding scales of variables, and a sweet little price to boot, for fans of Minesweeper, whatever your flavour is, this has you covered. Although, even in this updated version, clicking on the wrong mine in a final 50/50 situation and wasting the past 20 minutes of your life never stops hurting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026786565', 'num_games_owned': 971, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1461212383}
review:
[h1][b]Revitalizando um clÃ¡ssico[/b][/h1]

Fine Sweeper, game indie, casual que apresenta uma versÃ£o bem interessante do clÃ¡ssico game Campo Minado para o Windows, desenvolvido e distribuÃ­do pelo estÃºdio Pixel Prophecy, lanÃ§ado em maio de 2015 para os PCs. 

Para quem Ã© jogador da velha guarda e que sempre gostou de jogar qualquer coisa que estivesse disponÃ­vel, com toda a certeza jÃ¡ deve ter jogado, ao menos uma vez, nem que seja por poucos minutos o clÃ¡ssico Campo Minado no Windows, Fine Sweeper nada mais Ã© do que uma releitura desse clÃ¡ssico, com uma nova roupagem e algumas funcionalidades extras.

Para quem nunca jogou, o game Ã© bem simples, basicamente o jogador deve marcar as minas em um tabuleiro, sem cometer o erro de clicar nas mesmas, para isso ele deve observar os nÃºmeros que sÃ£o apresentados ao se clicar nos quadrados do tabuleiro, que indicam quantas minas existem ao seu redor, por exemplo caso o jogador encontre um nÃºmero um, isso indica que apenas uma mina existe ao redor do nÃºmero, se encontrar o nÃºmero dois, duas minas e assim por diante. Um game bem simples, mas para os que querem entender de forma mais clara as regras do jogo Fine Sweeper apresenta um tutorial em slideshow que auxilia nisso. 

Basicamente Ã© o mesmo jogo que conhecemos no Windows, com as mesmas mecÃ¢nicas, porem com algumas adiÃ§Ãµes interessantes, como a inclusÃ£o de vidas, que sÃ£o perdidas a cada erro e podem ser recuperadas ao longo dos nÃ­veis, ou a inclusÃ£o dos modos ClÃ¡ssico e Campanha. Mas o mais interessante Ã© que o game funciona em nÃ­veis, os primeiros nÃ­veis sÃ£o bem fÃ¡ceis e rÃ¡pido de serem concluÃ­dos, podendo ser finalizados em segundos, mas conforme se avanÃ§a os tabuleiros vÃ£o ficando cada vez maiores e com uma quantidade alta de minas, o que deixa as partidas mais longas demandando uma boa dose de atenÃ§Ã£o e paciÃªncia do jogador. 

De maneira geral, Fine Sweeper Ã© uma excelente game casual, que consegue fazer jus ao game que se baseia, dando uma bela revitalizada em algo que jÃ¡ era bom. Logicamente esse Ã© um game simples, indicado para os amantes de jogos causais e para os saudosista de plantÃ£o, que assim como eu se divertiram jogando o clÃ¡ssico Campo Minado. 

[b]InformaÃ§Ãµes adicionais:[/b]
Nota geral: 08.
Tempo dedicado ao game: 8 horas.
Conquistas desbloqueadas: 13 de 19.
Dificuldade: FÃ¡cil, ficando mais difÃ­cil nos nÃ­veis mais altos, mas a dificuldade fica apenas na exigÃªncia de mais atenÃ§Ã£o do jogador.
Fica a dica: Apesar de ser extremamente casual, nos nÃ­veis mais elevados, o game exige um certo raciocÃ­nio logico do jogador, portanto preste bem atenÃ§Ã£o nas informaÃ§Ãµes que o game lhe apresenta.
Gameplay: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pZoqPNaU2e0]Clique aqui.[/url]
Imagens durante a jogatina: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/luishq/screenshots/?appid=367000]Clique aqui.[/url]
Vale o preÃ§o? Apesar de ser um preÃ§o razoavelmente baixo, talvez seja mais indicado pega-lo com um desconto de 50%.
Modo de jogo: Exclusivamente singleplayer.
Idioma: Totalmente traduzido para o portuguÃªs do Brasil.

[b]Originalmente publicado no [url=http://portohq.blogspot.com.br/2016/03/analise-games-fine-sweeper.html]Blog PortoHQ.[/url][/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198020563701', 'num_games_owned': 3475, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 662, 'last_played': 1457131917}
review:
It's 2016. If you're not familiar with Minesweeper...I hope you wake from your coma eventually. If you hate Minesweeper, you're going to hate this. If you kinda like it, you'll most likely enjoy yourself here. If you dream of grids filled with flags and hidden bombs...this is a wet dream for you. It's [b]Minesweeper on steroids[/b]. Even at the full asking price it's worth the upgrade for fans of Minesweeper. On sale it's a no-brainer for even the most casual of minesweeping fans...

Pros -
[list]
[*] Campaign mode
[*] Choice between classic (single life) & updated (multiple 'hearts') mode
[*] Ability to restart from highest completed level
[*] Some neat power-ups
[/list]

Cons - 
[list]
[*] Music is rather repetitive...not bad...just repetitive
[*] Effects from explosions can make it hard to see tiles. Especially frustrating when you're going for speed on a level.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198131481432', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1480748784}
review:
An excellent reboot/remake of a classic Windowsware legend. Hours of labor, millions of dollars lost, and time well spent for thousands upon thousands of workers all playing Minesweeper instead of working is finally on Steam with new mechanics & fresh coat of paint.

If you like logic puzzles or Minesweeper, this is a definite buy... If you're not that into Minesweeper or have never played it before, I might still recommend it if it's on sale to at least try it. It's the best remake you'll find at this point anywhere.

review:
it's minesweeper, but with progressively harder levels and hearts

two hours into one session i was at level 30 or something with full hearts, and incredibly bored too; there's just too little risk and not enough reward

unless you really need a competitive scoring system i'd just stick to the original version which is almost assuredly preinstalled on your computer

review:
I spent my childhood playing minesweeper on old windows computers, but I had no idea what I was doing.
After all this time, I started playing this, and I learned the game in less than 3 minutes.
I feel like a goddamn idiot.

8.5/10 Great game

author: {'steamid': '76561198025674597', 'num_games_owned': 2061, 'num_reviews': 607, 'playtime_forever': 1082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1082, 'last_played': 1442292562}
review:
Minesweeper is back, because Windows without Minesweeper wouldn't be Windows. This game is a remake of the classical Minesweeper, found on Windows computers ever since the dawn of man, until Microsoft (wrongly) decided we didn't need it. It adds new stuff like lives and a sort of campaign mode that gets progressively harder. It also has the option to turn it into classic mode, in which there are no extra lives.

Another thing it adds are leaderboards, so you can compete with your friends.

It's quite good, and it has a nice jazzy soundtrack to get you in a minesweeping mood. I don't know what more to say in this review, only that if you're looking for a good Minesweeper replacement, look no further!

author: {'steamid': '76561197998961777', 'num_games_owned': 784, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1510693552}
review:
At last.
My pathetic skills on minesweeper are put to use.

On a serious note, the game is pretty nice, very nice effects, colorful, is quite forgiving and has a nice feeling to it. The only thing is that the songs aren't very... memorable, to put it simply.

As for the modes, You have a sort of "adventure" mode where you have 3 hearts, and you complete levels as fast as you can, with increasing difficulty. You can gather more hearts up to a maximum of 7.
Then there's your good old classic mode, where you can set the size of the grid and amount of bombs as you like.
There's global and friend leaderboards for each mode.

Is it worth it? Sure, as long as you get it for a really cheap price like I did.

All in all I give this game a 9/10. Grab it if you liked minesweeper.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010323210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1706768174}
review:
It's Minesweeper clone as you can tell from the title itself, only here you have more survivability, not to die from just one mine and also you can heal. As you progress, the mine positioning become more tight, you might need to play with Lady Luck beside you because of the 50/50 chance, but that's where the health system help, it keep you going. But if you like to got blown away by the mine, there's also Classic mode.

It's recommended for who likes Minesweeper, and also for you who don't know how to play, there's some simple tutorial, so don't worry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992120718', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1462813856}
review:
A gritty spiritual sequel to Minesweeper and its classic "beats actually doing my job. I guess" gameplay.

I'm still haunted by my partner's screams as he lay there, clutching the ragged stumps that used to be his legs. It should have been me that clicked that tile, Hasib. It should have been me..

author: {'steamid': '76561197985109343', 'num_games_owned': 2690, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1449060008}
review: This game gives the traditional minesweeper a nice polished look, but doesn't fix its flaws. Mines in corners are one thing, but situations with two equivalent options of mine positioning and no way to calculate it (since even corners are not safe) are quite common. There should be no luck or guessing in a logic game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063739378', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 462, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1448959058}
review:
Well, first, it's Minesweeper. If you're not in to the game in general, this version of it is unlikely to change your mind.

If you do like it, however, this is one of the better versions around. They offer a "classic mode" which is pretty similar to the original Windows version, and their own variation which is arguably better. I'll concentrate on that in the remainder of this review.

The major change is that you now get lives (hearts), of which you can have up to seven, allowing you to detonate seven bombs before the game terminates. Extra lives are dropped as you progress so if you're careful you should be able to handle five or so detonations per level indefinitely. While some might lament the loss of tension in this mechanic as compared to the traditional "instant game over" from a single detonation, there are situations where you simply can't know which of two possible layouts you're looking at, and you have to guess. Being able to do this makes the game less luck- and more skill-based, and also introduces the new mechanic of figuring out, when you do have to risk exploding something, what will leave you in the best shape after that move.

Along these lines too, they also appear to have removed both any chance of detonating a mine on your first move and the possibility of first moves that don't open the board enough for you to make an intelligent next move, as opposed to a guess. (I presume they do this by building the board only after you've chosen your first move.) Again, this shifts the game away from luck and more towards skill.

The standard "campaign" game has you clearing levels, starting with a small (5x5) grid where you need to flag three bombs, and eventually moving up to a full 20x40 grid with dozens of bombs. This gives a nice feeling of progression, and also makes things rather interesting and different from the original gameplay once you reach level forty, where you have to deal with a much higher bomb density (hundreds) than the original game ever offered. You can stop playing at any time and it will restart where you left off when you come back to the game. If your game ends, and you restart again from the main menu, you'll be prompted to start at any level you like up to the highest level you've ever reached.

The graphics are pretty decent, without being distracting, and I particularly appreciated their well done auto-open highlight. I use it a lot, and it's nice that it's easy to read in this game. (Auto-open is when you middle or right click an open cell to automatically open all non-flagged cells around it. If you don't have exactly the number of surrounding cells flagged as indicated in the cell on which you're clicking, you'll see a highlight of all unopened cells, allowing you to quickly and easily concentrate on the ones you need to flag.)

Custom modes, where you set the board size and number of bombs, are also available, and there's are also simple global and friends list leaderboards for comparing your score (which appears to be based on several factors, including what you expose and how many bombs you explode, but not on time taken). There's also a reasonable selection of achievements, and Steam trading cards.

All in all, this is a nice little time killer, and at $3 or less I think it's priced perfectly for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048808158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1450778319}
review:
Fine Sweeper is a better looking mine sweeper but with an important difference: a life/health system.

That last fact unfortunately destroys any and all challenge in the original. The levels do get progressively bigger with more bombs but the game is quite willing to barf life pickups onto each field that let you get away with a handful of mistakes.

Hexcells is still the best minesweeper knock-off around, but this is at least a nice visual update to an old classic if you're feeling nostalgic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993437321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 1089, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1665825209}
review:
A nice presentation of Mine Sweeper with a couple of nice, new features.

Auto-Clearing Option:
If you right-click on a cleared tile with a number (indicating how many bombs in it's surrounding tiles), and you have that number of marked tiles surrounding this number tile, all un-marked tiles will auto-clear.  Just be sure you marked the right tiles or the revealed bomb will detonate.  If you do not have the correct number of marked/flagged tiles around a number tile you can safely right-click on it to hilight the surrounding tiles and no new tiles will clear.  This feature increases the flow of the game tremendously.

Health:
Each time you detonate a bomb, you will lose a heart.  Lose all of your heats and it's game over.  When clearing tiles, replacement hearts will randomly appear as well as extra heart tiles to increase your total number of hearts up to seven.  I really like this approach, but I feel the game is too generous with how many hearts it gives you.  This makes the game a bit too easy.  It removes the tension you normally get when you play classic Mine Sweeper and you don't know if you are a mouse-click away from your explosive doom.

Graphics:
Simple space background graphics.  The planets are drawn crudely.  Subtle animated smoke and dust effects when tiles are cleared and when bombs detonate.  There is room for improvement, however:  Early levels (below 35 or so) have fewer total tiles.  The smaller tile graphics from later levels are used in these early levels and scaled up.  This makes the graphics look soft.  After you reach level ~35 everything looks sharper because everything is displayed in actual size.  Separate, larger tiles should have been created for these early levels so the graphics could look just as sharp as they look in later levels.  The entire game download is under 60 megabytes.  The developer had no reason not to create an extra set of larger tiles.

Aside from the soft graphics I meantioned just one paragraph ago (Remember?), the presentation is decent.  It could have looked even better with more dynamic lighting.  The tiles in this game are all evenly lit making them look like they could have been presented on a 16-bit console (other than the smoke and particle effects). 

The game does present some fun graphics pop-ups that appear with certain achievements along with animated fireworks.  If you have any achievements in Pinball FX2 you know exactly what I am talking about.

The game has modes other than classic mine sweeper, but I have not tried them yet.  I've reached level 38 in the main game and I can easily recommend this game for it's low price, clean presentation and the auto-clearing feature.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083867054', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1446518418}
review:
The key to restart the level DOES NOT FREAKING WORK, and there is no option to start a new game. I hate guessing and 99 times out of 100 blow up because of freaking guessing, and can't restart the level ^^. Lovely. And I presume me blowing up counts as a mistake. And the game just gave me an achievment for getting to level 10 without making a single mistake, so I am getting pis.sed that I can't restart a level OR start a new game from the main menu. I quit the game ^^. Thank you for the couple minutes of fun, but no thank you.

Also, I got to level 40 and started blowing up, so I blew up some more and quit to main menu after I lost all lives. From there, no surprise, there was again only the option to "resume", and lo and behold, I was in level 18.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000238022', 'num_games_owned': 1956, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1485233102}
review: I've always had a weak spot for Minesweeper on my dad's old Windows 98 machine and this game totally fills that void. Smooth, slick, and really well made. If you like Minesweeper and don't mind dropping a few bucks for a "new" version, then you should get this. I really like the campaign progression mode and the health system is great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048980407', 'num_games_owned': 2513, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 638, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 573, 'last_played': 1483423798}
review:
[h1]Short Review[/h1]
Fine Sweeper is a fairly enjoyable Mine Sweeper clone. Campaign Mode allows you to play through 50+ levels of upbeat colorful mine sweeping nostalgia. In this mode, you have "hearts" which you lose upon clicking on a mine, giving you a more forgiveable style of play. Although this game promises to never have your first click be a bomb, running into 50/50 situations is ultimately inevitable. RNG is a huge factor in whether you will be able to progress through the higher levels. Classic Mode brings back the traditional style of play where the game ends upon clicking one mine.

[h1]Score[/h1]
Good
- 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198035285721', 'num_games_owned': 5118, 'num_reviews': 1098, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1444371819}
review:
[h1]"Windows Minesweeper clone with heart containers and different gamemodes"[/h1]
You can either switch it back to classic mode which is like original Minesweeper (1-life option).
Pretty cool is the custom mode where you create your own field size (up to 36x22) and decide how many bombs you want to hide (max 790). In Normal mode you ascend levels with rising field sizes. There are also challenging timegoals to reach. Most grinding was to step on 5k bombs and set 50k flags.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025338306', 'num_games_owned': 258, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2066, 'last_played': 1693860130}
review: Great to see this piece of nostalgia get polished up with some more style.  However I am hitting my head against a minor usability flaw (as I see it) which is preventing my full appreciation.  When you click on a bomb, that bomb is replaced by a number and other numbers near it change as a result.  I understand the concept of "it blew up so it's not there anymore", but I'm not sure this behavior really adds much to the game.  In fact, 1) I have to question now what a number on an exploded bomb means, which can get confusing as you ponder whether to count the square its on, and 2) when you're deep in analysis of board state and click on a bomb, now your numbers have all changed making it a) really annoying to figure out WHY you made a mistake ("Now, what were those #'s??") and b) forces you to recalculate other moves you were pondering in the area.  I don't think that was actually your intended goal, but for me it jolts the user out of his/her focus.  Additionally, you don't need the number that replaces the bomb anyway, a person is trying their hardest to avoid all those locations already.  Would be nice to toggle this behavior in options so bombs you click on just stay... bomb blasts and no numbers appear or change.  But overall thanks for the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046980920', 'num_games_owned': 11755, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1502070003}
review:
Fine Sweeper is basically microsoft's classic game minesweeper.

For cad $3.29 , you upgrade your minesweeper experience by getting:
- Better graphics / animations
- Friends and global Leaderboards
- 2 modes: Classic 1 life and "campaign" where you have multiple lives and possibility refilling hearts

AAAAAAAaaaaaaaaand that's basically it

Compared to microsoft's free minesweeper, this is just a nicer version where and that's basically it. I was expecting more game modes or variations on the game.

I got this on a bundle so I'm quite happy with it, but for full price, maybe minimum 50% sale before I can recommend purchasing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104689437', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 65, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1446265145}
review:
This is absolutely great!  I've been a long-time fan of 'MineSweeper'... ever since the day a school friend's cousin FINALLY explained to me how the hell you actually play it!  In that moment a lightbult went off in my head, and I have been coming back to the game off and on ever since then (and I'm 31).

Enter 'Fine Sweeper'.  This game quite literally takes everything that made the original great, and improves upon the formula in just about every possible way.  Plenty of gameplay options allow for customizing the game exactly to your liking.  There are Steam Achievements and Leaderboards.  There's some nice, funky music that seems to lend itself well to the game IMO.  And, there's some color variation, adding some vibrance to the drab gray-tones of the original.  Taking all of the new features into account... if you want an experience akin or identical to the original game, that's an option too!

If you spent much time at all playing MineSweeper and enjoyed it, you WILL enjoy this game.  If you're like me and FANATICALLY played "Expert" for your best time, perhaps hours on end at times... well... this game is an OBVIOUS win!  The price is right, too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198088467344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6750, 'last_played': 1577633792}
review:
A fun update to a logic based classic game.  Up to level 40 you can rely on logic while paying attention to your choices.  However, after level 60 the game requires an extraordinary amount of pure luck in order to pass each level.  Some guessing is inevitable, but the amount required makes it a ridiculous waste of your time.
If guessing games frustrate you, stay away.

The only real hope for enjoyment is setting up your own custom games and picking the number of mines you feel is necessary to restore the logic aspect instead of relying on complete(and I mean complete!) LUCK.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009690028', 'num_games_owned': 4318, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 10474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7239, 'last_played': 1599448893}
review:
This game is a really hardcore yet casual version of Minesweeper. It sticks to the well-known basics of the game, but brings it to a far grander scale, the only item drops that the description mentions being extra lives (and some canisters to hold your extra lives early on), which is just as it should be.

And you'll need them all, you really will, the global 'record' seems to be level 67 right now which only two people have gotten, and I'm currently working on level 59, and I'm facing a 36x22 board with 219 bombs to flag and 7 lives (plus any others you find on the map) to do it with.

You'll learn so many new tricks and logical leaps out of necessity as to how to figure out the status of squares and try to narrow down the number of 50-50 guesses you have to make, which is why you have that many lives. It's a really engaging non-time-constrained puzzle game, exactly the kind of game that I love running in the background while I do or watch other stuff. Who knew Minesweeper could be so fun?

I didn't run into any bugs or glitches or have any complaint about the UI of the game. Yet. (Edit: I now have run headlong into a fairly major bug but the devs seem responsive and are working on it. (Edit: They fixed it!)) The one background tune it has is also a nice, non-intrusive, non-obnoxious track so I've left it on even after nearly 24h of off-and-on play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100994885', 'num_games_owned': 1826, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 15271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13827, 'last_played': 1585627027}
review:
50 hours in and I think it's time to write a review. Been playing it on and off rather addictively for the last month or so, most of that due to my unrelenting addiction for minesweeper (and achievements) as well as just wanting to top those leaderboards to make my life seem less worthless...

This is the best minesweeper remake I've ever played, it is a hell of a lot better then the windows remake that was on the windows store (not sure if they actually made it) which was a tragedy.
Like that one this too had pickups, which is an obviously new addition to the classic minesweeper formula and whilst I was pretty skeptical at first it's a very well incorporated addition unlike the other version. There is also classic mode where you only have 1 life and therefore you hit a bomb you die (just like in real life!).

This game has unlimited levelling (until I assume the board is literally just mines) but post level 60, odds are you're going to find it very hard to complete it. This put me off a little at first, since the game then revolved too heavily on luck and not skill but then if it'd be far too easy if everything was solvable by skill, there's not much to really make harder regarding skill in minesweeper.
The sheer difficulty of the higher levels have made me a much better player as I was forced to find new ways and rules to find bombs, which is something games won't normally do!

The graphics are nice but not too distracting and veer too far from the original minecraft, in other words there is nothing over the top and 'included because it's eye candy and omg luk at dem 4k textures'... Sounds are fine, bombs give a nice explosion (and leave a crater in the board) which can be quite unnerving when you're really focusing which brings a lot of tension to the game.

The devs seem to very active, I've seen a lot of activity in the forums from them and they seem to answer and adress the majority of problems that appear which is great. They seem to really care about the game and are not looking for quick monies, especially considering the price!

For Â£1.99 this is a steal, I think I got this in a greenlight bundle so I paid a lot less and feel like I robbed the devs and also took there clothes but I'd pay at least full price considering I've got 50 hours out of it and I don't feel like I'm going to be uninstalling anytime soon (#1 spot on the leader board here I come!). Even if you are not human and didn't enjoy the original minesweeper, you should still pick this up if you even have the very least bit of passing interest in minesweeper. Recent update made the earlier levels a lot easier so it starts off as a very casual game, perfect for wasting time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198039662270', 'num_games_owned': 945, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 109, 'last_played': 1436170806}
review:
(04/10) - At least playable

So what has this game going for it? There has to be something as itÂ´s based on a free game that is furthermore already installed on every windows pc out there.
Well, there is a mode with more lives so you donÂ´t die instantly, tho as a hardcore Minesweeper lover, thatÂ´s nothing for me.
One thing they did well is the first click: it is guaranteed to give you a start, and yes while this is not really innovative as other games did it as well by already revealing an area at the start, itÂ´s definetly a feature thatÂ´s missing in Minesweeper...

Tho they forgot to change the biggest flaw of Minesweeper. If they had done that, iÂ´d blindly recommend the game to anyone who likes Minesweeper... but they didnt: You still have to guess.
The more mines you add, the higher the probability of you having to guess meaning that the later stages will have a near to 100% chance that you will need to guess AT LEAST once, if not more times.

And as in any game: the word random should not be able to describe the game. Be it Hearthstone (a Hearthstone referene from a Minesweeper review, yes i did it) or any other game, it will decrease the value by an extreme amount.
So no, i canÂ´t recommend you to buy this game, as itÂ´s essentially the same game as the free version you probably already have installed...

Note: You canÂ´t tell me there is no algorithm for placing the bombs in a way that you donÂ´t have to guess. "Hexcells: Infinite" did it and they had a far more complex ruleset to work with. So yeah, i will just keep waiting until someone may eventually release this game without having to guess, until then, play something else...

author: {'steamid': '76561198013724696', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1621350319}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993891197', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 3265, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1457397803}
review:
It's a good Minesweeper remake! There are dozens of levels now instead of just three, Steam leaderboards to show off with, and the options and controls are just like how you remember them. (Plus, it's got a nice background track that sounds roughly like a cat playing Team Fortress 2.)

That being said, Minesweeper is much more boring than I remember it. It's mostly just a game of matching: spotting which numbers on the board are equal to the amount of adjacent tiles or flagged mines. The only real puzzle aspect to Minesweeper comes when you've spotted all the possible matches, and the only way to progress is to use some deductive reasoning on the remaining numbers. But no matter how hard you try, if there are too many mines clustered together in the wrong way, you're eventually going to have to start guessing, and that's ultimately Minesweeper's biggest downfall.

Luckily, Fine Sweeper gives you lives, so you can step on multiple mines on a level and still keep going. This introduces a completely new skill to the game: when stuck in a guessing situation, instead of just clicking and hoping you don't die, you have to pick the option that would give you the most useful information in a single click. It's a pretty nice touch and it feels like a good evolution of the game of Minesweeper.

But eventually the game starts cranking up the number of mines, enough to remind you of that one time you thought it would be hilarious to make a custom Minesweeper game with the maximum amount of mines, and then soon realized it was completely pointless and impossible. Despite the designer's attempts to balance the difficulty, it's inevitable in Minesweeper that you're going to have to guess a whole lot. But that's a problem with Minesweeper itself, and so this remake shouldn't really be held accountable for it. 

Although, it makes me wonder if the level generator could have included a bot that plays through the stage before it is presented, to make sure there are no necessary guesses. Or if there could be seeded boards with an automatic first click that are verified possible without guessing. But even though Fine Sweeper doesn't go all-out in bringing Minesweeper into the HD age, it's still good enough to be worth your time if you were, or still are, a huge fan of the old Windows games; it is a notable improvement on them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970476640', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1575473205}
review:
Fine Sweeper is, well, Minesweeper, but with some changes which I found to enhance the basic experience. The game is immediately familiar to anyone whoâ€™s played Minesweeper, and it also has a tutorial for anyone who hasnâ€™t.

The main mode of the game is a â€œcampaignâ€ style mode â€“ you basically start with a tiny board to clear, and each time you win you progress to a slightly more difficult board (the backgrounds and colors vary as well). Pretty soon (and I do mean soon, it doesnâ€™t take long to progress through the early levels) youâ€™ll be playing on boards even more difficult than the â€œExpertâ€ boards from Minesweeper. As you play through the campaign, you earn points for each mine you flag and each board you clear â€“ and you can compare your scores to other playersâ€™ on the leaderboards.

This leads me to my only complaint â€“ thereâ€™s no way to save your campaign progress. When you quit the campaign, your score is reset. You can still start at the highest level youâ€™ve unlocked, but your score starts at zero. A single save slot would allow you to continue the game through more than one session.

As you play, you randomly unlock and find lives, which are used up whenever you detonate a mine. This single-handedly fixes the main frustration I have with Minesweeper â€“ thereâ€™s no second chance if you guess wrong. Of course, once you run out of lives your game is over, but at least some of the frustration has been alleviated.

Custom game boards are included, so youâ€™re able to create your own challenges. And if youâ€™re not a fan of the new lives mechanic, you can play in â€œClassicâ€ mode to disable it. The developer has proven to be very responsive as well, pushing out updates quickly and regularly based directly on community feedback.

Fine Sweeper provides a comprehensive Minesweeper package and improves on the classic. Itâ€™s more than worth the low price point.

Full [url=http://www.thesewall.com/?p=569]review[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561197995762981', 'num_games_owned': 2047, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1439027253}
review:
If you gonna remake a game witch is free, and comes with windows by default, you really need to make it a lot better than the original game. Is this game better then original? It has some things going for it, but overall i would say no, and would recommend to play the windows version. 

Good side is live mechanic, which makes the 50/50 things little more forgiving. Almost every game of windows minesweeper at expert ends with at least one coin flip, usually around corners. Plus, maybe i'm just hallucinating, but in Fine Sweeper i had less coin flip situations.

However, the issue I have with the game is that the cursor snaps to grid, which makes controls really weird, and caused most deaths for me, or I end up wasting a lot time to correct a mistake, if I noticed it before next click. Also I don't like game graphic style. If anyone showed me a screenshot of a game, I would probably say that it was pre-windows version of game for DOS. But perhaps this is just me.

Anywhos, overall overall i would give this game 5/10, with windows minesweeper being at 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967419832', 'num_games_owned': 1365, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1678512284}
review:
It's pretty much a pretty version of Minesweeper, but you have extra lives, up to 7 maximum, so you can hit up to 7 bombs before losing, and you can also find health pickups when uncovering tiles so you can refill your lives 1 at a time. Of course, there's also Classic mode, which is without the lives like the original Minesweeper.

There's some convenience features, like if there's already a marked bomb next to a "1" for example, you can right click the "1" to auto reveal all tiles around it. Of course, if you marked the wrong tile you'll hit a bomb, but it makes things quite more fluid. Also, they altered it a bit so that the first click on a level  [b]never[/b] hits a bomb. 

You start at level 1, and as you beat levels it gets increasingly harder and harder. Once you've beaten a level, you can choose to start at that level so you don't need to start at the beginning every time.

My only complaint is that you cant save games in progress, so if you want to start at level 1 and see how far you can get, you have to finish that challenge in one sitting, else you'll either have to start over, or start at the last level you remember, which resets the score.

If you like Minesweeper, then this game is definitely worth the cheap price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080543482', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 7058, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1617584712}
review:
At the price for this game it is recommendable simply as a mess about game.  The layout is good and the ability to get a start is a a jump ahead of the traditional minesweeper.  The graphics are improved as well.

However, it is frustrating in the extreme when a bomb explodes and interferes with your ability to view the screen data.  Because of this the hearts that are given, (and not explained in the tutorial), are useless as the numbers are out of whack and you can't clearly see the field of play, (good vision is a most important aspect of playing a very visual game).  I was hoping for something that would be more manageable to play and be less frustrating.

In summary: You get a better looking mine sweeper game with a better starting move and the ability to custom make your screens.  I just sish that the hearts could be meaningfully used to complete a minefield and go on to the next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023807247', 'num_games_owned': 2390, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 37678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6646, 'last_played': 1523347504}
review:
[h1] Exactly what you expect: A minesweeper clone with a few extra features [/h1]

The "main" mode of the game puts you on a progressively harder sequence of levels. You start with 2 hearts (lives), which you can refill/increase from hearts hidden under tiles. The aim is to beat as many levels as you can before you run out of hearts.

Pros:
- Your very first move will always be a miss. I believe the bombs are placed after this. Maybe this is a bad feature, but no one likes to lose on their very first move.

Cons:
- No "restart level" button

If you want to play minesweeper, this game has you covered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060597598', 'num_games_owned': 3293, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1434734951}
review:
Let's not beat around the bush - it's just Minesweeper with a facelift.

It has a couple of flaws: it does have an element of chance in it rather than logic as there are some cases where there is no telling which of two cells has the mine underneath, and due to the progression you kind of just have to keep playing until you tire (which for me happened about 20 levels in, way before I felt in any real danger of losing). It also starts out very easy and takes a long time to build up to any real difficulty, although that is a matter entirely of personal preference.

On the other hand, if the idea of a game of minesweeper with a few app-like elements (added lives, some sort of social score thing popping up telling you how far ahead of other players you are etc.) appeals to you then this is a good implementation of this.

Overall, I'd say go for the Hexcells series if you want carefully crafted, more cerebral levels with absolutely no guessing and a higher difficulty threshold, but if you just want to sit and click in a faster-paced way then this may be the game for you. It's kind of the Bejeweled Blitz of Minesweeper clones.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198035428434', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1161, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1465158934}
review:
This game has perfected Minesweeper. You progress through levels of increasing difficulty and best of all it's very forgiving of mistakes and accidents because you have a handful of lives (hearts) plus random chances of finding more hearts under the tiles. Alternating color schemes for each level keep things fresh and some of the achievements are quite a challenge.

It's a light game but if you're a fan of Minesweeper then the small price is absolutely worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001053123', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 949, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 949, 'last_played': 1433995697}
review: A very solid version of Minesweeper. I like the progression from easy to difficult levels. And the life system makes the guessing much less painful for a while. The only preference I'd have is that checking neighbors with right click be performed on mouse button down only and not mouse button up. While going full speed, I'll accidentally put a marker in the wrong spot, and when I let go to fix it, I've inevitably moved a bit and do a check while releasing the button, thus costing me a life. Either that or I'd prefer the check be mapped to only both mouse buttons at the same time (or middle) like the original (or mappable would be even better!)
